item.title: The Leaving Women
item.description: In The Leaving Women, we have two women who meet on a train, Shelley and Leigha. Very different women who are both leaving something behind. They take turns telling their stories to each other as the train carries them further from their pasts.The Leaving Women started as a single poem and grew into an idea as I wrote more poems in a series. I have always liked the idea of telling a story through a series of poems. No dialogue, no plot devices, no world building. Just a series of poems that connect like a story. Like a concept album, a rock opera in poetry.In The Leaving Women, we have two women who meet on a train, the rebellious Shelley and quiet Leigha. They are both leaving lives and lovers behind to head for something unknown. They find a kindred spirit in each other and as the train carries them away from their pasts, they share their stories.Shelley gets her name from the famed poet Percy Shelley, who has always held a special place in my heart. Leigha is named after his good friend Leigh Hunt, also a poet, but one who enjoyed much less fame than Percy. Much like the balance between the two women in our tale. I won’t say much more about them because I want you to meet them for yourself.Quote I will no longer apologize for my fire. I will no longer cower before my own anger. I will own the spark that rises up like a shield against your condescension, You shoot arrows and expect me to accept the bleeding wounds  that come with your precision. ~ from the poem, For Too Long We’ve Been the Peacemakers Quote I was never very good at taking pictures of the moon, but this night the focus was crystal clear. “I don’t know if I like you or if you just taste like a memory,” I told him through the ruffled feathers of my second hand boa, on a night when the milky way loomed large across his freckled face. ~ from the poem, A Day and a Night on Purgatory Road Quote I made a man out of air and breathed him in to expand my belief that someday I would exhale him into flesh and bone. ~ from the poem, Man of Air

item.title: For You I Take a Breath
item.description: Do all poets write love poems? Maybe all poetry is a love poem to something. This is my collection of offerings to the volumes of love poems that speak to the heart. Love that works, love that hurts. Unrequited love, long distance love, soft love. It is through the words of poets that we learn that we are not alone in all the ways we love.this poem was supposed to be about love and it is if you read it as a letter written on an overcast afternoon with rain threatening and nothing to do but share the loneliness with someone waiting far away wondering and if you’re okThis collection contains almost 50 poems separated into three parts: love that doesn’t work, love that does, and love that pushes up against the erotic.Quote I confess I only wanted to dream with you while the rain beat the windows, your arm heavy on my chest, warming the very place I keep my sins. ~ from the poem, Sin Stained Lips Quote I won’t tell you how my heart skips and stops when your lungs stutter, breath catching in the bronchi like finely shattered bone. How my love rests like an apple slice in your palm, at the mercy of your lips. ~ from the poem, For You I Take a Breath Quote Can’t it drift like river ripples, bloom like pink petals? Can’t it be a peach skin love like velvet under your fingers? ~ from the poem, Soft Love

item.description: An offering of story poems. Here we enter into the realm of fantasy, whimsy, and storytelling. welcome to the garden
item.description:
I have had some sort of web presence/blog since about 1998. I made my own websites at first, journaled on various forums, had a LiveJournal, many Wordpress blogs, and have used various social medias as a type of diary. None of these ways of capturing my thoughts for public consumption quite fit the bill of how I wanted to express myself online. While I really enjoyed the community feel of forums and social media, there was always a pressure to respond and read everyone else before posting my own words. Having a blog felt too formal. Like everything had to be just right before I could put it out to the world. Polished, with the right photo, tags, categories, date created. After hitting "post" it was "out there," never to be touched or updated again. I'm a bit obsessive when it comes to these things and once the thing was out there with a published date, I would feel like I couldn't go back to it and change it. Where would it fit? With the old date or a new one?
I have been using Obsidian for note taking for quite awhile now, and enjoy the flexibility of undated, living, evolving notes and writings. When books had to written out by hand by monks, when pamphlets had to be printed at the printing press, when the only way to look up a fact was in the encyclopedia, perhaps it made sense to think of things as needing to be polished and finished before the expense was put forward to make a hard copy of a story, fact, or essay. But, we live in the age of digital ink, for the lay person who is keeping a blog or finding a way to publish their ideas, there is no reason for a polished final product.
As I have become jaded on the idea of keeping a formal blog, I still want to have an informal online presence. As I went down the rabbit hole of options, I came across the idea of a "digital garden." A place to learn in public, explore half formed ideas, and link one thought to another through building a "second brain."
I have been using Obsidian for note taking for about a year and it was the idea of linking notes and keeping "evergreen" notes that lead me to start a garden of my own.A reverse chronologically organized space with set dates implying that these things were finished, never to be returned to and updated, wasn't working for my curiosity driven, ever changing brain. Feeling the need to have every thought fleshed out and finished before sharing made me just not write at all. Feeling like the space needed to be polished in a perfect SEO driven format with perfectly aesthetic and glossy photos wasn't my style either. I enjoyed playing. Playing with graphics and fonts and layouts, but that took away from the actual writing. I also didn't want to be a "content creator." I want to be a real person putting real thoughts on a page to connect with other real people out there.Welcome to the garden! I hope you fall down a few rabbit holes and find your wonderland ❣

item.title: index
item.description:
Welcome to my garden! I hope you find a few rabbit holes to fall into while you're here ❣

This is the word playground that a blog could never be. Here I plan to play with different ideas (another thing that is discouraged in the world of blogging where every blogger must have a niche and only that one thing), publish things I'm curious about and not worry if everything is polished.
There are many other digital gardens or second brains out there to explore and many tools for building them.
I have built this garden by publishing my Obsidian notes with the Webpage HTML export plugin and hosting it on Github pages.Right now the garden contains a few different stages of growth:
00 Kelli AnnaThese are just random notes, lists, and things about me. A place to get to know me, a song of myself.
01 SeedsThese are just ideas for future use. Ideas for creative pursuits, writings, this garden, the future
02 SeedlingsThese are unfinished beginnings of writings and other pursuits. Half baked ideas, things to return to when the time is right.
03 flowersHere is where the more polished, "finished" work resides. Maybe these will still be edited in the future, but for the most part they have reached the last stage of growth and are at their most beautiful.
04 rabbit holesTopics I have fallen into and lost myself in for awhile. Nothing complete, nothing publishable, just learning for fun and mostly for myself. Learning should be a life long endeavor of rabbit holes and curiosities.Who knows what will grow here in the future ❣

item.title: Journaling Ideas
item.description: What am I hungry for?What do I long for?What do I crave?What do I desire?Seek and face our truths. Listen to our souls. Let live what must live. Let die what must die. Develop intuition to know what we need and desire. Be brave enough to head that call.Shadow Work Journal Prompts for exploring the Female ShadowIn what ways do I deny or suppress my own needs, desires, or emotions to maintain peace or seek validation?Are there any female role models, past or present, that I feel negatively about-why is this?What are some societal messages that I have internalized about what it means to be a woman? How do these messages affect my sense of self and identity?What are some ways that I may have internalized misogyny or sexism? How can I challenge and reframe these beliefs to support my own empowerment and the empowerment of other women?What are some ways that I may have suppressed or denied my own feminine energy or power? How can I reclaim and integrate this?How have I internalized shame or guilt around my sexuality? How can I release these feelings and embrace my sexuality as natural and healthy aspect of my being?Have I internalized the belief that I must always be nurturing and selfless, at the expense of my own needs and desires? How can I learn to prioritize my own needs and desires (while still being compassionate and nurturing toward others)?How do I conform to societal beauty standards? Does this feel authentic? If not, how can I embrace my own unique beauty and reject unrealistic beauty standards?Thinking about a time I was polite and accommodating in a situation where I felt uncomfortable or unsafe - how could I have set healthy boundaries, and asserted my own needs?How have I internalized the belief that I must always be competitive and aggressive in order to succeed? item.title: Fiction Ideas
item.description: Sometimes I silently beg for people to show me my worth - I think I must have been a bad person in another life. A villain in another incarnation. I must have taken all the praise for myself and never uttered a kind word. I must have neglected my children, pushed away love, and sneered at friendship. I must have held kindness like a precious stone, gripped in clenched hands, all for myself and not for sharing. I must have left so many people out in the cold - unseen, unheard, and uncared for. I think I must have been a very bad person in another life. Because no matter how much I give in this one, I am destined to remain on the outside. An empty cup. A lonely night. A restless ghost. Unseen, unheard, and uncared for. Kindness extended. Always. Hype given. Always. Cup filled. item.description: I had come here to be alone. I had silenced my phone and locked the door, but I stepped out onto the porch to soak in the sun that had been hidden over the long winter. The cement steps were cold underneath my jeans, but the sun was warm on my face. My eyes were shut to focus on the birdsong and traffic far in the distance when the sound of a car crunching over gravel forced open my eyes.He looked at me out the window for a minute before making up his mind and opening the door. Climbing out in one graceful movement of flannel and denim, glasses and trucker hat hiding his face while he walked up the walk, hands stuffed in his pockets and his shoulders rounded in apology or defeat. Did it matter?He sat down next to me without invitation and I resisted the urge to creep a few inches further away. I wouldn't concede my ground to the uninvited. The sun shone on his reddish brown hair and made his eyes squint into the middle age wrinkles that were usually invisible on his round face. He sighed and looked down at the grey steps."I tried to call. I know you don't want me here, but I had to see you. I had to make sure you were ok.""You just told me an hour ago that you don't think we can be friends anymore. So I'm not really sure why you are so concerned with my wellbeing."It wasn't easy to be angry with him. It wasn't easy to feel this emptiness where he had been for so long. Without looking at him I knew there was a mole over his left eyebrow. I knew that there was a scar on his chin where his brother had sliced it open with a stick when they were kids pretending to be Jedi. I knew that he was hurting now, but I couldn't bring myself to care or to ask why he had to turn that into hurting me."But don't you remember what it was like before?"I wanted to remember him as he was when I first saw him. 17 years old, shaggy hair in his face so the world wouldn't look at him too closely. He was standing with his bandmates off to the side of the old dance floor of the 1920s ballroom turned punk venue. I had just walked in with my bandmates for what was a weekend Battle of the Bands, a local thing that had been going on for decades. We had just arrived for the Friday evening pre-competition competition. Basically each band got one song to wow the judges enough to even get a place on the roster. I was also 17 and completely sure that we would get about 30 seconds on stage and then we would be boo'd off. Yes, our competition were all local punk bands of mostly teenagers who were probably going to be awful, but I was certain we would be more awful.I had tried to talk my brother Dave. our drummer, out of signing us up for this thing because I just didn't think I was ready to face a whole room of punks. We hadn't been a band that long and we had only recently found our bass player, Steph, who thankfully was also a girl because I was tired of only hanging out with dudes. Now she leaned in and whispered to me, "We could just leave. Couldn't we? I don't think I even remember how to play the whole song.""It's a punk song. It's like 3 chords repeated over and over. You are more than capable of that," I hyped her up. Yet, I was drowning in my own doubts in this room full of tattoos and Docs and testosterone. My brother slapped me on the back and said, "Look. I told you it would just be a room full of assholes who think they can play because they listened to two Green Day songs and now they think they're Billie Joe Armstrong. This'll be easy." Fuck if he didn't have enough cockiness for all four of us. I scanned the room mostly agreeing with Dave's comment. Mostly guys in skinny jeans and white t-shirts with a mohawk here and there. Until I saw him and his band. He was so scrunched into himself. A yellow t-shirt with some logo I didn't know, a baseball hat shoved on his brushed aside bangs, hair that hung over his collar. Old Chucks scuffing the floor like he couldn't keep still. He didn't belong here either. I could just tell."Hey - aren't those the guys from Social Index?" Our guitar player, Hank, had been around the scene with my brother far longer than I had and knew everyone."Yeah! It is! Thank fuck we'll have some kind of competition," Dave answered as he started walking in the direction of baseball hat/old Chucks and his band. We all followed behind, my heart hammering in my chest because I would have to perform in front of this room and because, honestly, I had instantly developed a little crush at first site on Baseball hat/old Chucks and I would have preferred to stay across the room making up fantasies about running my fingers through his fringe. Instead I found myself following in Hank's wake while I pulled Steph along behind me through the scent sea of body odor and old beer.I'm sure the ballroom had once been grand and had hosted big bands in suits and neatly trimmed hair. The walls were still decorated with art deco flourishes and balconies where the elite would have sat to look down on elegant women in shimmery dresses and men in tuxedos. Now it had been turned into a punk scene that was normally dark and loud and often violent. Young men getting out their frustrations by body slamming each other on the ballroom floor. (insert Sweet's "Ballroom Blitz" here) We had played here once, only recently as part of a showcase of local bands. When we weren't onstage I was up in one of the balconies trying to avoid the flying shirtless bodies. I had no idea what I was doing here. I loved the music but hated the scene. I wasn't even sure how I ended up in the band other than Dave had convinced me I could sing and play guitar decent enough to be in his band. Truth was, I could. Probably better than 90% of this room, but that wasn't what this scene valued. It was all attitude and anger and I didn't have a lot of either.As we closed in on Social Index, one of their members noticed Dave and grabbed his hand in a fist and said, 'Dave! Mother Fucker, I haven't seen you since Graphic Blandishment imploded!""Yeah, I was out of the scene for awhile while I rebuilt the whole band. I didn't want to make the mistake of getting in with a bunch of assholes again. You know Hank, right?""Absolutely! Hank! What happened to Staker?" "Also fucking imploded. Our bass player ran off with our drummer's fiance. Shit happens all the time, right?""All the fucking time. So, you guys know Andy and Steve, right? And this is our new guy Declan. Kid has a killer voice.""Can't wait to hear it!" Dave said. "Other than Hank, we have our bass player Steph and my little sister Beth. Guys this is Cody and the rest of Social Index."I had been hiding behind Dave, feeling more and more out of place in this scene where everyone knew everyone and most of the everyones were dudes slightly older than me. I had noticed that Baseball hat/old Chucks, or Declan as I now knew him to be, didn't have the testosterone dripping swagger of the rest of the room. He hung back, looking as nervous as I felt. When Dave said my name I peeked around him and found myself looking right into the eyes of Declan. He looked sweet, a little sad, a little lost and a lot like someone I wanted to know better.And here he sat next to me on a cold concrete porch step 30 years later. Still in a hat, still in his Chucks, still looking sad and lost, but now that look was because I hadn't let him finish whatever he was going to say after, "I don't think I can be friends with you anymore."Then he had the nerve to ask me if I remembered what it was like before. Which before? The one before we were just friends or the one before that when we were more?"Declan, I don't know what you want. What do you want me to remember? Why are you even here?""I'm here because you didn't let me finish what I was saying. I'm here because you got this look on your face like I had killed your dog. And I couldn't stand the thought it was me that made you feel that way when it could have been avoided if I was just better at saying the shit that's hard for me to say."He was looking at down at his feet, the ever present Chucks that he never tied all the way to the top. I knew everything about the man sitting beside me. That he loved comics but also novels. That he was constantly trying to learn a new language but didn't have the patience to see it through. That he had never quite accepted that he was a level of famous most people could only fantasize about and even then they got the reality all wrong. But I had no idea what he was thinking right now. I had no idea what he was about to say and that's why I'd turned and left and not let him finish whatever came after, "I don't tink I can be friends with you anymore" because I couldn't imagine life without him. I could barely remember a time I hadn't known him."So just say it. Just say whatever it is without feeling like it has to be some scripted grand whatever. Just say it."He sighed again and looked up from his feet to my eyes. "I've been thinking a lot about those months right after we first met."Those months. I thought about them a lot too.Neither of our bands won the Battle of the Bands that weekend at the old ballroom. I will forever argue that Social Index should have come in first just based on Declan's voice alone, but he wasn't traditional punk and what their band was playing wasn't what that crowd wanted. It was what I wanted and luckily, listening to them over the course of the weekend persuaded the other members of our band that maybe we could do more than the 3 chord, 2 minute punk song. Our bands had hung out the whole weekend and it was obvious we all got along really well and that our members almost paralleled theirs.Cody and Dave were both loud and crazy and attracted the attention of every woman in the room. It's like they were both born to be front men and yet, Cody was a bass player and Dave played drums. Steph and Andy were both straight edge and took immaculate care of their bodies. They were both awesome people. but preferred to just play the music and avoid attention. Hank and Steve were too smart to be in punk bands and should have been in college studying physics or something. They would get into deep conversations about the universe or some new technology and lose the rest of us in their ramblings.Which of course left Declan and I. The youngest members and the only two who weren't yet legal adults. In fact, we hadn't graduated high school yet. Declan didn't give a shit about his grades and was squeaking by with a C average. He only cared about music which was the only thing he excelled in at school. I wasn't anywhere near the brain power of Hank and Steve, but I cared about my grades and thought I would go to college when the band thing didn't pan out. Because let's be honest, it rarely panned out. Declan's parents were on him to go to college too, but he was really undecided about what to do.We were both the quietest members of our bands, front men and women who had only reluctantly accepted the role because we could sing. The punk scene in our area wasn't huge, so we ran in the same circles and eventually knew the same people, and ended up at the same shows. We pooled our small amount of money to rent a shared rehearsal space and spent stupid amounts of time together doing absolutely nothing.My crush on Declan only grew as I got to know him and realized that he was as sweet as I thought the first time I saw him. He was also intense when it came to the band and could have a real temper when the other guys were being stupid and he wanted them to focus. He didn't seem interested in dating or having a girlfriend, only in getting out of high school so he could throw all of his energies into music. And both bands were getting attention and there was pressure to do some local touring. Declan and I were the thing that was holding the bands back since we had to go to classes everyday.One afternoon I got to the rehearsal space early and sat on the old paisley couch that someone's mother had been throwing away. I pulled out the book I was reading for English while I waited. Declan showed up not long after, threw his backpack in the corner and collapsed next to me."I can't wait for the next month to be over. I can't even concentrate on this shit anymore. Why do I care about Algebra and writing fucking English papers. I only want to compose music.""I know. It's all a societal construct. I don't even know what I want to do with my life.""You want to front a successful band, don't you?""That's kind of Dave's dream for me. He wanted to be in a band and I happened to know how to play guitar and sing so here I am too. I really love music and the scene. It's fun. I just don't know if it's forever.""So be a writer then. It's the other thing you love," Declan had said this so easily. Like it was obvious to anyone and it was true. I did really love to write and I was always talking about ideas for all the stories I would write someday. Yet, I was shocked anyone had been listening. "Wow! I can't believe you've been paying attention to that.""Of course! The ideas you talk about are actual books I would read. Not the shit they make us read in school or the shit in the bookstore. You should do it."He stared at his Chucks and was quiet for a minute. His face moving in a way that said he was trying to decide whether or not to say what was on his mind."Would you ever date a friend?" he asked in a barely perceptible voice. Barely above a whisper. "I mean, like someone you've hung out with and know. Would you ever consider them as more than a friend?""I don't know. Is the friend you?"He jerked his head up from his Chucks and looked at me with a terrified expression, "Umm, well, I..." He breathed out heavily, "Yeah."I sat quietly for a minute wanting to savor this moment when my crush on him went from pure fantasy to reality. Just then the door opened and Cody and Dave poured in laughing and smelling like weed and the silent spell of just Declan and I was broken. His shoulders slumped forward and he muttered, "Fuck!"under his breath and then, "I shouldn't have said anything," I realized my silence had felt like rejection and as he started to get up I put my hand on his arm and just said, "Absolutely. I absolutely would if it was you."The rest of the bands showed up and it was music and more weed and laughter and chaos and Declan and I didn't talk anymore and I worried that he had changed his mind. But that night as I finished my homework and got ready to go to bed the phone in my room rang. It was him."So, I want to take you somewhere. Are you free tomorrow night?""Absolutely."The next night he took me to a poetry reading which I knew he probably hated and which made it all the sweeter that he had thought to do it for me. We held hands after on the way to the car. I kissed him chastely on the cheek when he dropped me off. And then I masturbated to the thought of him that night. As I had been doing for months by that point.We hid things from the bands because it seemed easier than enduring the teasing that was sure to come. We were friends in front of them, but saw each other whenever we could alone. Things moving from chaste cheek kisses to deep tongue kisses and under the shirt petting in his car.One night I got cocky and invited him to my house because my parents were gone and Dave was supposed to be staying at his girlfriends house. Declan and I were in the middle of what could have become the first time for both of us when suddenly Declan was ripped off of me and dangled in the air by a very red faced, very angry Dave. A very amused Cody laughing his ass off next to them. "What the fuck? That's my fucking sister you fucking little prick. You don't touch my fucking sister. I'll kill you."Dave didn't even realize who he had grabbed by the collar until Cody said, "Dave, DAVE! Calm the fuck down. It's Declan, man."Dave looked over at poor, blushing Declan and then at angry as fuck me."Dave! I am more than capable of taking care of myself. You don't have to come in here with fucking guns blazing to defend your sister's honor! It's not the 1800s! I am perfectly capable of making my own decisions about this!"Dave let Declan's collar go and Declan collapsed onto the couch next to me. "All I want to know is why you guys didn't tell us," Cody said."Because you're all fucking assholes who tease each other all the time and find the most sensitive thing about a person to pick on. It's fucking brutal and we didn't want that," I hoped it was ok I had said "we.""This very fucking moment is why we didn't say anything. We're barely individual people in this group," thankfully it seemed we were on the same page.Dave had settled down and looked genuinely sorry that he'd made such an ass of himself. "Alright. You're both right. But, I think the bands should know. It involves all of us if you guys break up and the vibe goes to shit."With that Dave and Cody left and I took Declan's hand. "I'm sorry. If you want to leave and forget about us, I'll understand." I would be devastated, but I would understand."Im not going anywhere. I don't care about 'the vibe.' I want to graduate and make music and I want to kiss you and talk to you and that's it. I... I love you. I'm not going anywhere."I gasped and could feel my eyes get big when I turned to him. "You... you what? You what?"He took my hands and looked at me. "I love you. You have to know that, right?"I shook my head, "No. But I love you too. Almost from the moment I saw you at the Battle of the Bands weekend.""When will your parents be home?""Not until tomorrow.""And Dave?"I shrugged. "I have no idea. He was supposed to stay with his girlfriend tonight and she's a real bitch so she'd probably be pretty pissed if he doesn't.""Do you want to finish what we started?""I... I haven't... I mean... ""Me either.""What? That's impossible! You're a cute boy who sings and plays guitar in a band. Every woman at those shows would want to fuck you.""1. I don't want to 'fuck' them or anyone. 2. I'm a band nerd. No one wants to fuck me. And that's not what this would be. Am I pressuring you? I'm pressuring you. Shit. Nevermind. I'll go home. Shit.""Dec. Stop." I stood up and took his hand. "Come with me." I started to lead him to the stairs and up to my room. "Wait. Do you have, you know... something... protection."He stared down at his Chucks again, "Yeah. Is that bad that I thought it might happen?""Fuck no! I'm glad we don't have to wait." I wrapped my arms around his neck and kissed him. He enveloped me in his arms. "Let's go."And it was better than I had imagined when I had imagined him in my bed all those nights alone. He fit just right and he smelled like home and I didn't care about all of the other cliches that went through my head at that moment. I wanted it to last forever."What about them? We left that behind a long time ago.""Yeah. But they were pretty amazing.""Yeah. But you ended it. You were the one who wanted to be free. You were the one who left to go on tour and left it behind.""I know. I stand by the fact it was the right decision at the time. We never would have lasted as two eighteen year olds being launched into the stratosphere the way we were with the bands. We would have broken up eventually and in a way that might have meant we couldn't be friends like we ended up.""Yes. I agree. I was devastated at first. I hated you for about a year, but we did overcome it. So, why the fuck are you telling me that we can't be friends now?"Another deep sigh and another scuffle of his Chucks. He adjusted his trucker hat and squinted into the sun."Not that I don't want to be friends. That I'm struggling to be just friends. It's killing me to see you everyday in the studio and not be able to tell you how I feel. We haven't spent this much time together everyday since we were 18 and It's reminding me of everything I loved about you and what a dumbass I was not to see it sooner. I will be friends if that's all we can be, but.... I really want more. We're both divorced now. It's the right time!"I had wanted more for so long. And then he got a serious girlfriend and I had to give up and accept his friendship. And for a long time it had been enough.Once Declan and I graduated, there wasn't anything keeping us off the road. We started touring locally and seeing each other less and less. They were gone. We were gone. They recorded a record. We recorded a record. We got to spend time together when both bands got booked to Warp Tour but that's when it took off. That's when Social Index was launched into stardom and signed with a big label and booked to a huge tour. That's when Declan decided he needed to see what that was like without a girlfriend back home.I understood what he meant. I understood the reality of the situation and how it made sense, but it still hurt like fuck and I hated him with all of my being. Our bandmates took to our corners and barely spoke. Just like Dave had predicted that night in the living room. My band had my back and wouldn't see the the guys from Social Index, even when I told them that was silly. We stayed apart for almost a year. During which time we also got a record deal and launched a tour.And I came to realize that Declan was right when I was making out with the lead singer of the band we were opening for and his hand was inside my underwear making me squirt all over him. We had been babies. We never would have lasted through the pressure and ridiculous schedules of the road. Not to mention the opportunities for casual hook ups and tour bus blow jobs.Our bands were slated to play Warp Tour again the next year and it was there that we all started hanging out again. When I could finally tell Declan I understood and was glad why he had broke it off. When we went back to being friends. Over the years I dated actors and musicians and he got one steady girlfriend who wasn't in the business but seemed to understand the crazy schedules. They got married and I went to the wedding alone. And cried in my hotel room after with Steph holding me and telling me she understood. That she had always thought Declan and I were soul mates.I started dating an actor who was always on location which was fine because I was always touring. We got married even though we barely knew one another. Dave got married, and divorced, and married again. Hank got married. Steph married our long time manager and had a baby. Steve had a baby and then got married. Andy got married and was content with dogs instead of babies. Cody had been the cover boy for the whole scene that our bands started. The pressure was immense and the paparazzi intense. He took too many pills one night on Warp Tour and Declan found him in their room. He was sure Cody was dead. But, he made it and got help and had a kid. The years went on and we were at each other's weddings and celebrated births and had parties and BBQs and played music and toured and grew up and older.Declan got divorced first. After his wife revealed she had been seeing someone else for the last five years of their marriage. That fucks a guy up and Declan threw himself into being an amazing dad and musician, I got divorced a couple of years later when my husband and I realized that we had spent 20 years being apart and hardly knew one another. We parted as best friends and co-parents and I love him with all my heart, but not as a soul mate. That space has always felt occupied,A few months ago the record company realized that Social Index and Yeah!Nadia shared a history and a fan base and that it would be awesome if we recorded some kind of collab album and toured together. It was suddenly like the early days. We were sharing a rehearsal space and writing songs together and seeing each other everyday. The only difference was we were surrounded by family life. Spouses and kids and demands outside of each other. Declan and I both had kids at college so we were more flexible than those with little ones at home. We stayed in the studio writing or playing music together late into the night.And yes, I had thought that maybe I was feeling something again. But, I thought it might have just been nostalgia. I had gotten an electric charge when our hands met. I had wanted to kiss him when he was leaning over the control panel towards me. I had wanted to throw his guitar aside and mount him on the studio floor. But, I tried to remember the way it hurt everyone when it ended before and how much more we had to lose now."What if everyone gets hurt again?""Does that mean you feel it too?""Dec, I don't think I ever stopped feeling it which is probably why I married a guy I spent very little time with. I didn't have to face the daily guilt of being married to him and loving someone else," I stared at my own shoes when I said that in case it was too much too soon."I know that guilt. It's why I couldn't even be that mad when it turned out Mia had been fucking someone else for five years. You and I have always been meant to be. I just wish it hadn't taken me so long to realize it.""You were right to end it all those years ago. We never would have survived the fame at eighteen. We were able to be friends again because you ended it before it could all go bad. Yes, there's regret, but our kids grew up knowing each other and the bands are all still close. I think you're right. It's time now."I took his calloused hand that had played songs for millions. "Do you want to finish what we started?""I don't know. Do you have protection?" He smirked."I do. But not for my heart." I groaned at the cheesy line."No worries there." He kissed me on the cold porch steps and time righted itself the way it does when things that are meant to be finally... be.

item.title: The Letter
item.description: Dearest Ward,How the years have passed by and changed us both. How the time has made us into who we are today. We have lived lives unimaginable and now we are within sight of the finish line. What a race it’s been! How strange to have more miles behind us than in front. But, I’m babbling on and you, I’m sure, are wondering why I’m taking the time to write after all these years. After so much water under the bridge. Or maybe you’re not wondering. Maybe you have also seen the checkered flag awaiting you and have looked back at and analyzed every turn. And maybe you have seen the places where it all went wrong.You are my turn that went wrong and as I sit in a house built on other people’s secrets, a life built on other people’s pain, I am alone. There is no husband, no children, not even a cat to feed and take care of. There is only the empty regret that I spent a life immersed in the work of tearing down lives. Some deserved, some maybe not.Maybe that’s why you left. We all have secrets and you wanted yours kept. But I have the unholy compulsion of digging under it all and surfacing what people would rather keep hidden. I’m sure you sensed that there were times I was mining your past as well. Digging through your thoughts and actions. It’s what detectives do. But, I never seemed to learn when to leave that at the office.Not that there ever was an office or an official title. No place to hang out a sign. People just seemed to find me when they needed me. To seek me out when the solution escaped them. And I put everything together in a nice manilla folder for them. Tied up the loose ends and, even when the end wasn’t what they wanted, I always hoped it had brought them closure and peace. Maybe I would should have left well enough alone in some of these cases.But, I do know I helped people find peace and helped find people who shouldn’t have been walking free. So, now, when my eyes and ears are failing me and I’m no longer able to suss out the truth, I have had the time to sit and suss out mine. And my truth is that, even as I gathered clues and pieced together facts, even as I prided myself on being a woman “Sherlock” and seemed to see connections no one else could make, even as I was able to coax secrets from people, I could never access my own secrets. I could never piece together myself. There wasn’t time! One case would end and another would come. My mind was forever engaged in a world beyond my own! But, I don’t have to tell you that, do I Ward? It’s why you finally left. I was always the case I was on and never a whole person.I have time now. Hours and hours of time. I’ve sorted through old cases and locked them away. I’ve cleaned the layer of dust from my home. I’ve read the books that I bought over the years and never had time for. I’ve worked through the distractions in an effort to keep me from having to examine myself. Maybe that’s what all of the years were. A distraction to keep me from myself. But, I’ve had a look now. The woman I see is old! When did she get old? I barely remember being young! She’s alone. She has a lifetime of memories that belong to other people. Most of all, she regrets never knowing what a lifetime of memories made with you would have been. I’m sure you have a lifetime of memories of your own. You and Maria. I was so sad to hear of her passing, Ward. I was never the jealous type and she was an amazing woman. Maybe there will be a time, after you read this letter, when we can sit down and you can tell me about your wonderful life. You’ll have to do all of the talking, because my stories are only the stories of others. I don’t know what I’m asking for here. Just a chance. A chance to get right what I got so wrong! I don’t know if you’ll see me as worthy of that chance, but I need to reach out and try. I don’t want to die without my own memories. I don’t want to die with regret. So even if we just sit down over a glass of wine and talk about the old days, it will be at least one memory of my own to sustain me.I hope to hear from you soon, Ward.Yours, Stancile2018

item.title: Fresh Sheets
item.description: Around a campfire in what used to be a city, in what is now the rubble of civilization, four survivors sit. Eating the rat meat they’ve cooked over the fire and a few rations of packaged vegetable substitute. Grimacing as they eat, the two who are old enough to remember share stories of the comforts they knew before the fall. The younger two think they’re making things up. Teasing them into believing that things were ever other than what they are now. Even if they were different, they could never have been as good as these two claim. But, the reminiscing continues.“My mother used to fry pork chops in an inch of oil! Man, I even miss the terrible greens she made us eat on the side! Couldn’t have the cake she made for dessert if we didn’t eat the greens! After dinner we’d head back outside for another hour of play before dark. Streets lined with houses, lawns, streetlights. It was just never dark back then. Now it feels dark even in the daylight,” Toby rambled on. “What about you, Old Lady? What do you miss?”I look up from my packet of vegetable substitute, the texture of green applesauce, and clear my throat. I don’t usually participate in these memory throwbacks, what’s the use? It’s all gone and it’s never coming back. But, something’s been on my mind the past few days. One moment I would love to return to even for just a day. I clear my throat and begin.“When I was a child I lived in a small house with six other family members. I know now that’s not very many, we pack people in houses twenty deep, but at the time it was unusual. I lived with my parents, my grandparents, my great grandfather, and my uncle. It never seemed crowded or chaotic to me, but I bet it was. There are so many things that I know you guys think that we elders make up, but it was true! It was all true! We ate dinner at a table together every night. Sometimes hamburgers and fries that no one had to cook. Someone just stopped and picked them up on their way home. My grandmother was a terrible cook, but I miss even what she used to make. My mother on the other hand could make a meal out of whatever you had on hand. I miss her Easter hams with pineapple slices. Don’t look at me like that, child! It was real!”“I’ll back up that story, Lady!” laughed Toby. “I remember the hams too! Butter shaped like lambs. Crazy shit!”“I forgot all about that lamb butter!” I laugh. “Maybe it’s better some things have disappeared. Anyway, it’s not the food I’ve been thinking about lately. It’s the beds. A soft bed all to yourself. A clean bed just for you. My bedroom in this house full of chaos was in the basement. We had divided up the basement to be almost like a little apartment.”“What’s a basement?” asked the younger of the brothers that Toby and I had taken under our care. Orphans like so many others. Headed for trouble like so many others. And trouble took on a whole new meaning when stealing was just a way of life now. Toby still had this crazy belief we could make the world a better place. Take in a couple of kids, set the world on a straighter path. I couldn’t see how they had a chance in hell of being anything but outlaws in a town with no walls, but what have you got if you haven’t got just a shred of hope.“Many houses had a main floor, level with the ground that you walked into. Then there might be stairs going up to a second floor. Usually that is where the bedrooms were. We only had one floor above ground in this house, but there were stairs that went down to another level below ground. That was the basement.”“You mean it was like dirt walls and floor? How didn’t it cave in?” Asked the older brother.“No, the walls and floor were made of cement. It wasn’t as fancy as the upstairs, but it was solid. We had these roll down curtain things that we put between the rooms we had created. A living room with a couch and TV, my parent’s room, my uncle’s room, and my little area of the basement. With a bed, a table, and I suppose a place for my clothes. The other part of the basement was for storage and laundry. Anyway, I didn’t always want to sleep in my area of the basement. I liked to sleep upstairs where it felt like a real house. My grandma liked to spoil me, so she would say yes sometimes. We had a couch that had a bed inside! The bed just folded right out and I would sleep there sometimes.” I paused letting the memory soak into my bones. I felt my body relax a little and I sighed. Willing myself not to tear up. Toby put his arm around my shoulders. Nodded his head for me to continue. “You’re making me feel more hopeful, actually warm with this story. Keep going if you can.”I nodded and took a deep breath. Another bite of rat meat. Grimaced with the taste of reality, and continued. The boys were wide eyed and leaning forward to drink in more of the past.“My strongest memory of sleeping on that couch bed was in the summer. It used to get hot in the summer, but not like it does now. Now you almost have to stay inside until the sun goes down. Then the days were long because there was no school, bright, sunny, and green. Nights were quiet, and cooler. A breeze coming through the screen door.”Toby holds his hand up to the younger boy who was about to open his mouth. Probably to ask what a screen door is. “Later,” Toby mouths.“The night sounded like crickets and frogs and smelled like fresh mown grass. I would climb into bed in that semi-darkness of a house asleep. Light filtering in from the outside lights. My grandmother’s sheets had the freshest smell. A little hint of bleach, a little hint of being put away in the linen closet for awhile. They were soft, and the blanket had a silky edge. My grandfather snored like a train, but it was soothing. Everything was safe and the future was certain. And I’d fall asleep secure in that house of people who held my history. While cars would pass occasionally, the frogs would continue to sing. And I would just sleep. That might be the most unbelievable part of the story! Sleeping without waking for a whole night. Sleeping without a look out. Just sleeping.”My voice wanders away and Toby stares ahead lost in his own memories of summer and sleep. The boys are quiet staring into the fire. The rats and vegetable mash forgotten. We all look up at the sky and watch the stars which are more visible than they ever were when I was a child. That’s something we have that’s better and we hold onto those little dots of light and dream of the other things that can be made right.2018

item.title: Unfinished Novel - The Keystone
item.description: { or maybe it was only ever meant to be a short story }I don’t remember entering the worm hole. I don’t remember taking a step into a swirling vortex and riding it til it dumped me unceremoniously into an unknown life. I only remember the offer. That a man appeared as I was shoveling the snow for the tenth time that winter. That he seemed to appear out of the snowfall itself. Materializing as a swirl of flakes in a white down coat and jeans. Blue winter hat and shaggy surfer hair.He smiled and asked me if it was time. From his pocket he pulled a smooth stone and held it out to me in his mittened hand. I looked at his kind eyes, his open smile, the red of his cheeks from the cold. I felt relieved to find a sign of life in the swirling snow, the cold, and the silence of a February morning.He asked me why I was shoveling when it was still snowing. I said I wanted to get on top of it. Not have so much to shovel later. Besides, my afternoon was free and I had little other to occupy me. He asked if I would like to change that and he nodded toward the stone. A small, smooth stone of a pinkish hue. Swirls of burgundy brown.The stone that would abandon me for periods of time and then return like long lost heirloom. The stone that ruled every decision I had made since I was seventeen. Sometimes I would be away from it long enough to forget that it was waiting for me. On this particular afternoon I had been without it for over two years. Its memory had faded like the colors of summer were now lost to the white day. I had thought this time I was free from its influence.I suddenly remembered that he’d spoken, asked me if it was time, asked me if I’d like a change. I took a minute and thought about the last year. The last disastrous year, and I nodded.The kind smile grew wider and he held it our further from his chest. “I thought so,” he said. “Go ahead, take it. I’ve been taking care of it, but really it has always been your keystone.”I reached out my own gloved hand, realized that I needed to feel the smooth, cold outside of the stone for myself, and removed my glove. I again reached tentatively toward the stone. As my cold fingers came closer, I felt its heat radiating like tiny tendrils reaching to envelop my fingers and I felt a familiarity. I felt a homecoming in my fingers. I touched the stone tentatively and the air started to hum.“Remember,” said the man, “wherever you land, that’s where you were always meant to be.”In a swirl of snowflakes the neighborhood and the man and my snow shovel disappeared and I was being swirled into the very air that created every flake of snow, every drop of rain. I was swirled into a snow tunnel of glittering, majestic, choice. And I took a left.And now I’m here. Lying on my back in a field of wildflowers. My hand clutching the stone. Looking up into the face of the man in the mittens, only he’s wearing a t-shirt and the sun is playing against his shaggy hair.He grins at me, reaches down and takes the stone from my hand, tosses it in the air, catches it in his fist, and begins walking away through the field of flowers.“Wait!” I call. “Where am I?”His pace doesn’t slow as he grins over his shoulder “Right where you are supposed to be,” he calls back to me, then disappears into an arch made from the limbs of dense trees in what I take to be the entrance of a forest.I look around. Perfectly puzzled. Thoroughly perplexed. I was shoveling snow on a cold, windy, grey day and now, I am lying in a field of blooming wildflowers, with the sun beating like mid summer. Bees are buzzing, leaves are providing an orchestra to the day.I look down and I am dressed in lightweight flowered shorts and a white t-shirt. Old, battered sneakers on my otherwise bare feet. The man’s words echo back to me, “Right where you are supposed to be” and yet, no where I have ever been beforeThe trip is always disorienting. For a time after the stone leaves my hand I always feel a bit like I am a newborn. Nothing makes sense, my legs are uncertain under me, and the memory of what came before is like a fuzzy dream. There is never time to think about the decision to leave. Only time to remember that there was a reason I made that choice.I stand up and take a look around. I thought I must have been miles from nothing, but I see there is a town up ahead and a house not far from the field I have landed in. There are cars and buildings like the ones I have left behind, so the change won’t be too disorienting. I haven’t landed at the feet of a knight drawing his sword or in the space age emptiness of an alien world. Just another reality like so many I’ve left before. I take a tentative step wondering if this will be a day trip or if I will be here for years like the home where my snow shovel is now being used by a woman who looks just like me, but isn’t exactly me.I seem to smell saltwater on the summer breeze and I feel a great relief that I must have landed near the ocean. There have been places with no water and they have made me yearn to always live near the sea. Just as I’m pondering this, a man walks out the door of the nearby house, looks around, notices me and waves me over with his arm.“Come on! We’re going to be late! Unless you want to walk to the store, come on!”Another stroke of luck. Byron is in this reality. I always miss him in the places he was never born. He needs a haircut and his t-shirt looks like it would be better off in the landfill, but it is good to see him. It’s been a few realities since I could rely on my older brother. “Why are you roaming around in the wildflowers when we need to be getting to work?”“Ummm, it’s just such a beautiful day and I feel like I haven’t seen the flowers in so long. After such a long winter."“Did you hit your head on something while you were rolling around in the flowers? Winter’s been over for months, Shell. Now get in the car!”He seems a bit frustrated with me, but then Byron is often frustrated with me when he happens to end up in my life. As much as there is always love between us, there is also  his need to take care of everything and my need to fight him every step if the way.I get in the car and turn to him with a grin, “It is so good to see you. I can’t tell you how relieved I am you’re here.”“Ok, now I know you hit your head in that field.” But, he returns my smile as he turns the key and a Foo fighters song from many a timeline starts playing on the car radio. Sometimes the jump is just right.“If you want me to pick you up for work, I don’t mind, it’s on the way, but could you be ready to go next time instead of communing with nature?”“Sure. Yes. Sorry,” I manage to stammer. “I just feel a little out of sorts today.”“It’s understandable with all that’s been going on. But, it’s going to work out, really. We’re going to figure out how to keep the store and how to continue to pay everyone and it will work out somehow. This was our dream. We won’t let it fail.”I wish I had some idea of what he is talking about. I look out the window at the town passing by. Not tiny, but certainly not a metropolis. Clean, well maintained store fronts. People passing on their way to wherever it is people go at whatever time of day it is. It was late morning when I touched the Keystone. I glance around the dashboard looking for a clock and see that it’s 11:30 am. So, not much time has passed since my toes were freezing in the fresh snowfall. I wonder what date it is, but figure I really should try to play it some kind of cool before Byron decides he needs to worry about me.I try to muster up a response to his cryptic words about a store. “Yes, I guess I have been more worried about it than I realized. I know we’ll figure it out. It’s just been a lot to think about.”“Of course it has. Not only the threat of losing the store, but you having to travel back and forth to New York to meet with a publisher that is making demands that seem very unreasonable for a first time author and they way you have been splitting yourself in two for months. Keeping the store going, writing, traveling. It’s too much. I keep telling you it’s too much.”Too much. Just my luck to have fallen into another existence that is too much. I was shoveling snow in the middle of a snowstorm because I had suddenly found myself with too much time to think and too many reasons to want to get out of my head and into my body in the middle of a freezing February day. If I was going to find myself thrown into a life right in the middle of it, couldn’t I have chosen one that wasn’t too much?I didn’t know how to reply so I just watched the town slip by, listened to the radio, and tried to figure out how I was going to once again pretend to be someone I had never met before.It was always hard for him to leave her dropped right into the middle of a new life. No matter how many times he presented the stone and she took it, he felt like he was abandoning her over and over. In the beginning, when he was the new guy and she was still a teenager, he had begged to be able to explain to her what was happening. Why couldn’t she know? Why couldn’t he just tell her that it was her fate?But the answer was always no. The answer was always that this is how it has always been done. The answer was always that she must choose a life of her own. The time would come for explanations, but not today. Not at the beginning. Not right after the choice had been made by the stone.He would disappear into the woods or a crowd or into thin air if there was no other choice. He had learned not to look back. He had cultivated a joviality in these moments that hid his ache in not being able to run back and explain everything. The ache that no matter how many times they went through this, no matter how much he knew of her heart, she didn’t know him at all.He was a ghost in a snowstorm, a smile on a crowded street, an apparition on a foggy beach, a familiar stranger again and again. A constant in her life, but a constant that only appeared when things went wrong.He had practiced exactly what he would tell her when the time came that he could explain it all. When they let him tell her how she was chosen as a child of air. When they had summoned him this time he thought it was for the purpose of explaining everything. After all, she had been in that place for so much longer than any other. But, as soon as he saw the snowy street, her slumped shoulders, and the grey of the sky in her eyes, he knew that it was just another opportunity for the stone to take center stage. It still wasn’t his time to tell her everything.The store turns out to be a bookstore on a quiet street leading to water in the distance. A pale pink awning readsTwo writers meet because they share a publisher (and an editor?). They live on separate coasts and have other jobs to supplement the meager income of their book sales. She lives in New England and runs a bookstore. He lives in California and does web support for his brother’s company. They meet in NY at their editor’s office. She is a huge fan of his book and sees him as the perfect man. He has not yet read her poetry collections, but he does after meeting her and gets the feeling they are very much alike. They go out to dinner that first meeting and stay in touch a bit long distance. A big book convention is coming up and their editor/publisher thinks they should both attend to get fans excited for their next books. Which they are both struggling to write. The end up spending 3 days together in an airbnb because the publisher thinks their books compliment each other and wants to keep them as a sort of “team” throughout the convention and thinks they should know each other better to do that. They do end up closer and finding that they feel a lot of the same things about the nature of life and maybe each other. Then they have to go back to their lives apart. And she has to decide what to do about the secret she hasn’t revealed to anyone.She isn’t sure how she got to this existence. She doesn’t know how she was shoveling snow on a sidewalk one day when a man appeared out of the swirling snow and handed her a stone that seemed like something she had lost although she had never seen it before. As soon as the stone touched her hand she became part of the snowstorm and opened her eyes into a sunny day in a wildflower field with the man walking away into the woods calling out that he hoped this one would stick. A man who claimed to be her brother called to her from a house and suddenly she was riding in a car to the book store they owned together and was living a life she was just dropped into the middle of. She wrote poetry to deal with all of the secrets she couldn’t tell anyone. How did she get here? When her collection was published, the man showed up again one night as she was closing the bookstore. In the hush of the books and the coffee smell and the night at the window, he told her her own story.That she had been here long enough now to choose. Stay or go. The stone he handed her was the key to her destiny. Every time she became uncertain about the timeline she was in, he showed up and handed her the stone. If it was time to move on, she was transported to another timeline. Another of the many multiverse that held another existence. She had been in the last one for many years, which is why she had forgotten about the stone. The longer she stayed somewhere, the more the memory of escape faded. But she and the stone were linked by history and he was her guardian through timelines. When it became obvious she was not in the right timeline, he always showed up and the stone always knew. After two years, he would show up like he had tonight and ask her if it was time. If she chose to stay, the memory of how she got here would fade. If she chose to go, no one would know as the her of this timeline would resume her place. How many times had this happened? She wanted to know. How many times have we had this conversation? What about my real parents? My real family? My real timeline? She demanded. How much history had he stolen to drag her through existences?As he had many times before, he gently explained. She was a child of air. She was born into an existence of smoke. She was fated to find the timeline she could do the most good. Like her ancestors before her, the only family that mattered was the one she chose. Yes, she had left behind other parents, other siblings, even a child here and there, but they didn’t know. They weren’t harmed by her choice to go. And it was always her choice. Whether it felt like it or not. She had been fated by the muses to move through the barrier of existence until she found the one where she could inspire, uplift, and create. In other timelines she had been a lawyer, a politician, a cult leader, a musician. A daughter, a sister, a mother. An olympic gold medalist. And in each of them, she had done some good. Some of them didn’t last 2 years. In some she knew sooner that it was time. In others, she knew it was time, but she was hesitant to go. In the last timeline, she had been an activist with a large family and a husband and child. he had come to her at the two year point and she had told him that she believed this was the one. This was where she could do the most good. He had taken the stone and believed that would be the last time he saw her. That he would now be the guardian of another child of air. Oh, yes. There were others. Her true sisters and brothers. But, then her husband had had an affair and in her despair, she had stopped being active in trying to change her community. The day she had been out shoveling snow, she had just taken a job as a cashier in a grocery store to pay the bills. Her child had just told her that she wanted to live with her dad and his new girlfriend. And life had taken one of those turns that life sometimes takes. That lets us know we are not on the right path. Most humans either decide to make a major change and maybe turn things around or they settle into the despair and disappear into themselves.But she, as a child of air, as one chosen to do all they can to make change, she had another choice. And that morning in the swirling snow, she had made it without even realizing it. The stone had let him know and there he was again. On another street, in another town, handing her the same choice. And the part of her that remembered her purpose had taken it. And here she was. And now was the time to choose again. Stay or go.She couldn’t see why, if these were the rules, she would be given the option to stay in this timeline. All she was doing was running a bookstore that was barely solvent, writing poems, and falling hard for a guy who lived on the other side of the country. How was she changing the world? She posed this question to the man across the table. The guardian who had known her forever, but who she didn’t remember at all. Why this timeline? Why this existence? She had been an activist, a civil rights lawyer, a politician. Here she was just a lovesick poet. How could that change the world?But, haven’t you learned, that love and words are the only things that ever have changed the world? That they are the only thing that really matters?

item.title: 06 Chapter Six - Interlude Two
item.description: I can feel your frustration with this story. I can feel that you think there are many important things I have left untold. And you're right. You have questions, I get that, so let's pause for another moment for a little Q&A. Just shout out your questions and I'll try to answer as best I can.Q. You mention how close you were to Dave and then he just falls out of the story. What's up with that? A. I think it can just be something that happens as siblings get older. We went to different colleges, we chose different paths. He was never happy with my choice to reconnect with our dad, even though I had no regrets about that. My dad had stayed clean and found fulfillment as a grandpa. I tried and tried to get Dave to just try with him, but there was too much hurt in him to look at what could be on the other side of it. Dave and I stayed in contact, we kept up with each other's lives, we visited and made an excellent uncle and aunt to the other's kids. I just stopped looking to him to steer me. And he never figured out how to allow me that space. There wasn't a falling out, just a drifting that felt like the glacial creep of the continents leaving Pangea, until we were further apart than we realized.Q. What about your mom? Where are the other women in this story? A. That is an excellent point. You're absolutely right. It has been a bit male dominated, hasn't it? I suppose that's a bit of a squeaky wheel gets the grease phenomena. My mothers (I always felt lucky that Dave's mom was as loving to me as my own mother, and Dave felt the same about mine. We call them our moms.) were nothing but supportive, strong, independent women who taught us that, in a male dominated world, it was the women keeping things together behind the scenes. I never grew out of touch with them. I talked to them weekly at least the whole time I was in the Seattle area. I asked them for advice, I cried on their distant shoulders, and I relied on them heavily when things were ending. They do deserve a starring role in my story. I'll take that into consideration.Q. I feel like I know more about a guy you slept with a handful of times in your teens than about the man you were married to for 22 years. A. That's not a question, but that's true. My husband was an extra even in our own lives. He was a walk on role that had a line or two and left the scene. I wish that wasn't the case, but I have to stick to the script. He was an actor and I never really knew which him was the real him. He was dedicated and charming and ran his hands over my midsection like he worshipped Rubenesque paintings. I think that was the real him. The first months of our daughter's life, I think that was the real him. Happy and content with a baby sleeping on his chest while he studied a script for another bit part. But, then he got the actual role. The actual come to the studio everyday and be a bit player in this sitcom. And people recognized him occasionally. And then that was him. He was a star. A minor celebrity who didn't want a wife and two kids. he wanted to be free to run his hands over the tiny waists of his co-stars. He wasn't evil. He wasn't abusive. He just wasn't. Wasn't there. I had experience at playing the quiet ghost girl, so I took the lines from my mother's award winning roles and applied them to my mothering, but I never made myself whole enough to ask for more. It was relief when he told me that it was over. I had been waiting.Q. What about your kids? Don't you feel like you should have stayed for them? A. No. I don't and I'm kind of shocked you would say such a thing in these modern times. My kids were 23 and 21 when everything imploded and they weren't stupid. They had lived with their father missing for years. They have lives of their own and wouldn't want their mother to continue in something that made her feel like an extra in her own life. I love them dearly, but honestly, this isn't their story, nor my story to tell on their behalf.Q. Your dad was so integral in the backstory. Why is that when he seems a minor player in the real thing? A. I know that Facebook has made it seem like we need to stay in contact with every person who has ever come into our lives and that they should have an equal role throughout, but that isn't how real life is. Just like my brother and I were closer when we were kids and lived together, just like Jay was the first man who showed me how gentle love could be, but faded into the past, just like my ex-husband now has a life separate from mine (we have stayed friends for the kids and our own peace), my dad was so important when I was younger simply because he wasn't there. He was a figure I had to make up in my mind. I romanticized him until his absent presence formed me into who I became. Once we reconnected and he stacked up one sober year after another, he was just a man. A man who I was grateful to have in my life, but he became just my dad and my kid's grandpa. He was integral to the backstory, just like Dave. Then he was just a part of the comforting background noise of my days instead of the out of reach guitar solo he had been when I was a kid.Q. You say you were this quiet bookworm of a girl, but you sang in a punk band, wore fishnets, and got fucked in backrooms of nightclubs. I don't buy it. Were you a wallflower or the whole fucking rose bush? A. You're question is framed in the mythical binary of either/or. I had to be this or that. One or the other. This is the fallacy of all or nothing thinking (yeah, I've been to therapy). I was and am both. There was something about that punk scene. Something about being in that band, that brought out a deep soul wounded howl. I let out every bit of the pain I hid from everyone on that stage. And I numbed the rest by fucking men who couldn't have cared less about me in dark places where they couldn't see me cry. I was the quiet bookworm, the saintly mother, and the howling punk rocker on my knees with a dick in my mouth. I am multi-dimensional. (Look up the lyrics to Meredith Brooks's song "Bitch." Then we'll talk some more.)One more question then we really need to get back to the story - Q. You're not very good at this are you. A. Motherfucker, I told you I was once writing a novel that starred an alien trying to be a popular girl. What do you think?

item.title: 05 Chapter Five
item.description: I was crushing hard on my neighbor. I thought that at fifty, I had left this side of me behind in the clubs of Seattle. The last drummer (Who would later go on to be a drummer for two pretty major bands, but as he was the drummer, no one really knew his name. Yet another minor celebrity encounter.) had fucked me in a janitor's closet and then called me a fat ass and told me to leave. It was the rare time that I didn't feel good about embracing my sexual freedom. I was always glad I had gotten married after that and became a respectable mother. Family gave me a place to do penance for my past sins. Every blown out diaper, all night crying spell, violent stomach flu that needed to be cleaned from the carpet, every night when my actor husband didn't come home and I was left with a teenager heartbroken over an ending friendship, was another bead on the rosary of forgiveness. It was another Hail Mary toward being a "good" person. In the end all I ended up was a non-person. Someone with a past she tried to hide and late night panic attacks that I had made a fool of myself for decades. So, to find myself lusting after my neighbor in my new life, was quite a surprise.My new apartment was small. There were two bedrooms and a pullout couch so the kids could come home, but really, it was tiny. It reminded me of when I was living in Milwaukee and working at the website all those years ago. But now I could appreciate having a space of my own. A space not taken up by scripts and mountain bikes, school books and backpacks. My mom had been nice enough to let me store boxes of memorabilia at her house so I still had some of the kid's old clothes and toys, but my apartment was unapologetically my own. My oldest had a good job in Toronto as a linguist. My youngest was about to graduate and start a master's degree in politics. They had their own lives and didn't need a shrine to their younger selves in their mother's home. A few pictures, some children's books they loved. It was enough to keep them close.Otherwise, it was earth tones and floor to ceiling books. A desk with a laptop where I was struggling to reclaim my voice. At night there were the faint strains of music coming from the apartment next door, if I wandered out onto my tiny balcony, I could hear the music even louder. Strains of Pearl Jam, Prince, Tracey Chapman, and what really hooked me, Rancid. Although I think the night I decided to knock on my neighbor's door, it was Lionel Richie singing "Stuck on You" that lead me like a cartoon dog floating through the air after a scent.I didn't knock on the door with any pretense in mind. I wasn't there to ask said neighbor to turn down the music or to borrow a cup of sugar. I just had to see the person who's music so often exactly matched my mood. I slipped out into the hall in my sock feet and knocked at the door. After a few seconds it was opened by a guy around my age, dark blue t-shirt, kind brown eyes, tasteful mustache that made me realize I had never kissed a man with a mustache before. I was so distracted by this idea that I didn't hear him say hello until he asked a little more loudly if he could help me."Oh, right, hi," I stammered. "I'm your neighbor next door and I was just coming by to...""Ask me to turn down the music? I know it's probably too loud, but your apartment was empty for months and I got kind of used to being alone on this end of the hall." He looked at me with a sheepish grin that tugged at something that hadn't been tugged in a long time."No, no. It was the music that made me come over, but more to compliment your taste than to ask you to turn it down."I bowed my head in what I hoped was a shy, flirty move and realized I had knocked on this man's door in pajama pants and an oversized Foo Fighters sweatshirt that had seen better days in the early 2000s. I hadn't really prepared to meet anyone, I hadn't really thought this through."Compliment me?" he asked confused by my rusty social skills."The music. I've been enjoying the songs in your rotation. It's trippy how often they match my mood."He visibly relaxed and exhaled, "That's so awesome. I was really worried I had been a bad neighbor. Although, I should have come over and introduced myself sooner. I'm Carlos." He reached out a hand and I noticed a tiny spiral tattoo between his thumb and index finger."It's nice to meet you. I'm Beth." (Of course I was Beth. Remember my father's obsession with thinking he was a roadie for Kiss? Dave's just lucky his mother didn't allow our dad to name him Gene.) I took his hand in mine and felt swallowed by the size and like I was caught in that spiral for just a moment."Would you like to come in? I was just about to play something a little newer. Maybe some John Legend?"The mention of John Legend snapped me back to reality. That felt like music a man put on to lull a woman into staring into his eyes while he snuck an arm around her waist and slowly tucked her under him before she knew what hit her. And I was a long way for being ready to be tucked under anyone right now."Maybe another time. I still have work to do on an article that's due tomorrow to my editor. I'll take a rain check on the John Legend for tonight. It was nice to meet you though. Finally."He looked at me and I swear steam was rising off of his shoulders and his gaze and for a moment I hesitated and thought maybe I could be tucked under someone after all, but then he smiled, gave me a little wave and shut his door.I breathed out. And tried to remember if I had put my vibrator in my nightstand. I really hoped the batteries weren't dead.
